CHIEF COMPLAINT

Acne follow-up.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient No. 014. He is a pleasant 20-year-old male who presents today for an acne follow up. The patient was last seen at his last visit on 03/3/2021 and was prescribed clindamycin, tretinoin cream, and benzoyl peroxide wash 4 to 5% for face and 5 to 10% for chest and back. He denies any signs of redness, peeling, dryness, or irritation with use of these medications. He washed his face last night with the Benzoyl Peroxide wash, and put the antibiotic, Tritonicum, and sunscreen moisture stuff. This morning he washed the face with the benzoylecidin, and applied the antibiotic and the sunscreen moisture cream. He also applied the tennoin cream last night. He notes that the acne on his face has improved and that he has not put much effort into the current treatment. He confirms that he is happy with how things are going. Regarding his acne on the back and chest, he would recommend using a higher-than-recommendation amount of benzoy
PHYSICAL EXAM

Breast: There are less than 5 inflammatory papules on the forehead, cheeks, chin, and nipples.

Skin: Mild to severe ecchymosis in the face, mild on the back.
Neck: Normal.
Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Skin Peculiar: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
VITALS REVIEWED

Examination of the scalp reveals scalp follicles are in tact. There are no masses of skin redness, peeling, or irritation.

No redness, peeling, dryness, or irritation with use of these medications at all.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Maria Martin is a 76-year-old female who presents for a follow-up visit. The patient was last seen 2 months ago when her a1c was 9.9 and she was advised to increase her Glimepiride by 2 mg to 4 mg twice a day. She denies any headaches, dizziness, or nausea. She reports that she is trying to eat healthier, less carbohydrates. She does not like pasta, but she states that she does not have any in the house very often. She usually has 2 to 3 slices of bread per day and 2 peanut butter sandwiches in the morning. She has a history of peripheral neuropathy in her legs and hips and pain in her hips and upper legs. She states that her feet feel like hell all the time. She is unable to do much walking due to her lower extremity pain. Her blood pressure was 116/74 mmHg a couple of weeks ago, which is slightly elevated due to the medication she is taking. She continues to smoke, but denies she is ready to quit.


PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
VITALS REVIEWED

Hematologic/lymphatics: There is no murmurs, gallops, or rubs to palpation of the bilateral lower extremities. There is mild left paraspinal muscular tenderness in the right upper quadrant, which may be due to guarding mechanism.
Neurological
Paleoactive bowel sounds in all 4 quadrants. They are normal.
Bilateral right and left lower extremity reflexes are intact.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

X-ray images of the eyes were obtained and reviewed today.
Impression: Moderate-to-high A1c 9.9.
Peripheral neuropathy.
Hepatic chondromalacia.
Lipid panel: Elevated.
Abdomen: 116 mmHg.
Welch Elevation: 4.2 cm2.
Patient: Immediate release of Creatinine: 4 mg twice a day.
Maintained hemoglobin A1C: 9.3.


ASSESSMENT

• Status post op cataract surgery.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current health conditions. I have recommended that we make changes to her regimen today, including increasing her Glimepiride to 4 mg twice a day and decreasing her Lisinopril to 2 mg once a day. We have also recommended that she discontinue all forms of alcohol, including alcohol with over-the-counter refills. She can continue to use Cipro at this time.
INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up in 1 year or sooner if her symptoms continue.

dialogue: [doctor] michelle king , date of birth 1/5/1986 , mrn q227631 . new patient visit for acid reflux . past medical history of anxiety and seasonal allergies . [patient] hello , are you mrs. king ? [doctor] i am . [patient] i'm dr. phillips , very nice to meet you . [doctor] you as well . [patient] how can i help you today ? [doctor] well , my primary doctor , dr. scott , he referred me here . [patient] okay . [doctor] i've just got really bad acid reflux . [patient] okay . can you tell me more about it ? [doctor] yeah . so i mean i , right now i take 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day . some days it is fine , but others are just really bad . what do you feel ? [patient] it feels like burning . [doctor] in your chest ? [patient] yes , in my chest and also in my throat . [doctor] in your throat and chest , alright . any difficulty with swallowing ? feels like food or liquids kinda get stuck ? [patient] no . [doctor] okay . that's good . any abdominal pain ? [patient] no , not really . [doctor] nausea or vomiting , changes in bowel movements ? [patient] no . [doctor] constipation , diarrhea , rectal bleeding ? [patient] nope . [doctor] okay . very good . and how long have you had this problem ? [patient] i've had acid reflux since i was around 12 , but it has gotten worse over the past few years . [doctor] okay and how long have you been on the omeprazole ? [patient] on the way it is now i think about a year . [doctor] okay . do you find that it's done anything for you in the past ? i mean i can tell it's helped because some days i'll be fine and then some days i eat something and it feels terrible . are there anything that make your symptoms worse that you can pinpoint like food choices or stress ? sure , probably stress and food choices sometimes . okay . what things bother you ? [patient] spicy foods so i try not to eat them too often but sometimes even drinking a soda can cause it . we do know that caffeine and caffeinated beverages will do that even sodas even just the carbonation can cause that . how about tomato based products or citrus products ? [doctor] yeah sometimes but i still eat them . okay . it's reassuring that you are n't having any difficulty swallowing though . how has your weight been ? pretty stable ? [patient] i would say pretty stable although i have n't had much of an appetite for the past 2 months . i have been under a lot of work stress . [doctor] what do you do for work ? [patient] i'm a paralegal . [doctor] okay and any family history of gi issues ? [patient] my grandmother had esophageal cancer . [doctor] on your mom or dad's side ? [patient] mom's side and my mom had some issues like acid reflux and she was taking some medication that coats the lining of your stomach . [doctor] okay . have you ever had an upper endoscopy ? [patient] i think maybe when i was younger . [doctor] but not in the last 10 years ? [patient] no . [doctor] have you ever tried any medication other than omeprazole ? [patient] at one point i was on omeprazole and ranitidine , it did help . [doctor] but other than that , those are the only medications i have taken . [patient] okay . have a seat here and let me listen to your heart and lungs and then we can talk about a plan for you . [doctor] okay . so normal physical exam per my new patient template except for a well-healed abdominal surgical scar is noted . what's the surgical scar here on your abdomen from ? i always forget about that surgery . i had it when i was a baby . my mom said my intestines were twisted , so i had to have surgery when i was around 1 month old . gotcha , okay . so let's talk about what you have going on . from what you've told me , it sounds like you've had a several year history of gerd , which is the medical term for acid reflux . [patient] and recently your symptoms have been poorly controlled with the omeprazole 40 mg twice daily . you've been having heartburn despite taking this medication , correct ? [doctor] yes . and you've identified trigger foods like spicy foods , carbonated beverages , citrus , and tomato based foods , but you have n't cut these foods out of your diet completely yet . [patient] so the first thing i'd try is changing your diet because these foods can exacerbate your gerd even though you're taking the ppi . [doctor] okay , yeah , i could definitely do a better job of avoiding those foods . [patient] great . so stress is another trigger that we need to address . high stress can cause worsening of your symptoms . [doctor] yeah , stress and anxiety are definitely big problems for me . so working on that may help with your gerd . additionally we can consider trying a different ppi since the only one you've tried up to this point is omeprazole . if you're okay with this , we can switch your omeprazole to nexium . that's fine with me , i'm definitely open to trying whatever . perfect . i will send a prescription for nexium 40 mg twice daily to your pharmacy on file . i also recommend that you have a procedure called a egd or upper endoscopy to look for potential causes of the gerd . we sedate you and then pass a small camera through your mouth down your throat , through your stomach and end in the small intestines . [patient] we would look for any ulcers or signs of precancerous or cancerous conditions that we can take biopsies at the same time if we see anything . [doctor] okay . can i schedule that today ? yeah , you can get scheduled at checkout desk . i'll have you follow up with me in the office for the egd so we can discuss the results and talk about how you're doing with the dietary stress and medication changes . how does all of that sound ? [patient] that sounds good . [doctor] perfect . i will walk you to the check out desk . be sure to call my office and let me know if anything changes or if you have problems before your egd and follow-up appointment . please insert the procedure paragraph in the plan . i suspect that she likely has gerd with underlying functional etiology as well . reassuringly , she has no unintentional weight loss and denies any dysphagia . if her egd is normal and her symptoms persist despite a trial of nexium , we can consider a trial of protonix and obtain a ph impedance study . this will allow us to rule out abnormal acid reflux exposure and to decipher between a functional etiology and hypersensitivity .
note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Bad acid reflux.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Michelle King is a 39-year-old female who presents today for a new patient visit for Acid Reflux. She was referred by her primary care physician, Dr. Scott. The onset of her symptoms began around 12 years ago, but they have steadily worsened over the past few years. She reports that she takes 40 mg of omeprazole twice a day, which has been effective on some days, but not on others. She has not had an upper endoscopy in the last 10 years. The patient states that her symptoms can be exacerbated by stress and food choices. She denies abdominal pain, constipation, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding. She is employed as a paralegal.


PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Bilateral breast tenderness noted.
Cervical
No tenderness to palpation of the cervical spine.
VITALS REVIEWED

Abdomen: Breast is in tact. There is a 1/2 incised scar on the right side of the breast which may be caused by radiation or chemotherapy. The patient is being seen regularly for monitoring. No additional treatment is needed at this time.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

X-ray of the abdomen is reviewed and revealed a well-healed abdominal surgical scar.
Impression: Moderate-to-severe acid reflux.
Abdomen: Moderate to severe.
Lipid pH: About 7-8.
Hemoglobin A1c: Approximately 7-7.5.
Echocardiogram: Negative.
Magnesium pH: 4-4.2.
Urinal sinus congestion: Moderate.
Treatment: Omeprazole, 40 mg twice a day.


ASSESSMENT

• Status post coronary artery disease.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regard to her current symptoms. I have prescribed the patient Omeprazole 40 mg twice a day. She should continue taking this medication and I have also recommended a low-glycemic diet modification program. We will also review the possibility of an upper endoscopy to assess for possible contributing factors to her symptoms. All questions were answered to the patient’s satisfaction.
INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to assess her progress.

She pooed and felt much better after she got home. Michelle's white blood cell count was elevated at 23,000. Michelle was discharged after clinical improvement of her symptoms.


ASSESSMENT

• Follow-up recommended.

Michelle King is a 39-year-old female with a history of quadriplegia due to prior spinal cord injury. She presents today to follow up regarding her symptoms.
• Urinal tract infection.
The patient was admitted to the hospital on 6/29/2021 and was discharged on 7/2nd. She was treated with i.v. and antibiotics. Her white blood cell count was elevated at 23,000, but she was discharged after clinical improvement. She is constipated and has not pooped for 2 weeks. The last time she did, her blood pressure was elevated and she threw up. She also had a fever, which may have been related to the fever. Her urine culture was also elevated, but her urine is normally normal. The most likely source of the infection was a UTI, although her urine did not appear to be stained with any bacteria. The patient is symptom-free at home, with the exception of a slight fever that she attributed to the heat. She will follow up with me in 2 weeks to check on her progress.
INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up recommended.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up with primary care physician.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ashley James is a 14-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney. She is a previously healthy patient. The patient was found to have a small kidney on one side and a larger kidney on the other. She reports a lot of pain in her right side and reports burning when she eats. She initially came home 1 day sick with symptoms of a stomach virus. The next day she was twice as bad as the first day. She was diagnosed with an infection and sent back to Jacksonville, where she was seen and treated for 4 days. She has improved slightly, but she has not had any more throwing up or anything since then. She continues to have symptoms of pain and fever.


objective_exam:

Neurological
Bilateral Atrophy of the right kidney: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Cardiovascular
No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.


Musculoskeletal
Exam of the heart: Nontender to palpation of heart and lungs, otherwise there is no murmuring, galloping, or ringing in the ears. There is some extra fluid on the right side of her abdomen that might be due to an enlarged lymph nodes. The left side is clear to auscultation without additional fluid.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

X-ray images of the right kidney were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal an atrophic right kidney with cyst or cyst-like growths on the kidney and ovaries and maybe some other places. The right kidney is smaller and less developed than the other one. There is an infection present. The primary care physician is out of town on vacation. The patient is in pain and complains about a lot of pain in her stomach. Her lymph nodes were swollen and they found some infection. She has not had any more throwing up or anything since.


ASSESSMENT

Ashley James is a 14-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of abnormal renal ultrasound with an atrophic right kidney.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regard to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms appear to be related to an acute kidney infection. We discussed the course of treatment and that she should continue to follow up with her primary care physician for further evaluation. I also recommended that we obtain a CT of the kidney. The CT was ordered today and the results are expected to be available in about a week. All questions were answered to the patient’s satisfaction.
INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up with the primary care doctor as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right handed male, 60 years old.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Martinez is a pleasant 60-year-old right-hand-dominant male who presents today for evaluation of numbness and tingling in his right wrist and right elbow, and mild stiffness in his neck. He sustained a right wrist injury in a motor vehicle accident last December. The symptoms began to worsen after the injuries healed and he wore a splint for approximately 1 month. He denies any loss of sensation in his hands or fingers. The patient states that his numbness is more noticeable at night and throughout the day. He describes his symptoms as “a zing” in the right wrist. The left wrist also exhibits some numbness, but the patient notes that the left wrist has improved over the last month. Mr. Martinez reports that he has been taking Lexapro for anxiety. He has a history of prediabetes, which he was able to control by changing his diet.


PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological
Examination of nervous system reveals fatigue, weight gain, bloating, increased risk of heart attack, stroke, gallops, etc.

Musculoskeletal
Exam of the right and left hands reveals decreased sensation in the 3rd and 4th fingers. Sensation is normal in the 5th and 6th fingers, but decreased on the 7th and 8th finger. Decreased sensation on the 9th and 10th finger, bilaterally.
Bilateral Erythema
Motor neurone disease
Gastrointestinal
Lungs are clear to auscultation, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.


objective_results: #####EMPTY#####.

X-ray of the right wrist is normal.
Impression: Bilateral tingling and numbness of the bilateral extremities.
Tests: 1+ and symmetric. 2+ knees, 2+ bony tibial arches, 3+ fingers, and 2+ toes.
Nervous system review of the review of systems is negative.
Brain activity: 1.
Echocardiogram demonstrates decreased pinprick sensation in the 3rd and 4th fingers on the right and decreased in the 4th and 5th fingers.


ASSESSMENT

Mr. Cook is a 60-year-old right-handed male who presents today for evaluation of bilateral bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome.

Motor neurone disease.
• Right handed male present today. He is a car accident survivor and had bilateral wrist fractures in his car wreck last December. He continues to have tingling and numbness in his right wrist despite splinting it twice a day since the accident. The left wrist also exhibits some signs of irritation but is not as severe as the right one. We reviewed the patient's examination and radiographic findings today. I have recommended that we obtain a bilateral tachometer to evaluate bilateral bilateral paraspinal tunnel syndrome bilaterally. The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to determine his results. If his results are consistent with this diagnosis, we will proceed with a lithotripsy. If not, he will be referred to a neurosurgeon for further evaluation and possibly a whole-body scan.
INSTRUCTIONS

The patient presents today to see his primary care physician for treatment. The first step in the treatment plan is to administer Neurontin 500 mg once a day as needed to treat the bilateral bilateral bilaterally ting

Significant reductions in bilateral tibial acetabulum volume. Significant changes in bilateral hand reflexes. Mild to moderate arthritic arthrogramtosis. Mild osteoarthritis. Triglyceridemia. Significant reduction in bilateral bony curvature. Cervical anterosuperior plate level. Cushing's syndrome.


ASSESSMENT Shirley Taylor is a 60-year-old right-handed female new patient referred by dr. jacob ward for evaluation of bilateral hand numbness and tingling. She presents with symptoms similar to bilateral cubital tunnel syndrome with a right hand. Mild right-hand bilateral brachial artery sprain and bilateral left-hand bilaterally tibial nerve sprain are hallmarks of bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome. We will treat her conservatively with continued use of the splint we have provided her with. If her symptoms do not improve over the next month, we will consider further imaging or referral to a hand clinic to evaluate for possible surgical intervention such as epidural neuromuscular fistula or bicep tendon graft. All questions were answered to the patient's satisfaction.

note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mrs. Hernandez is a 44-year-old female who presents today 6 weeks postoperative. She is doing well and has no pain. The patient reports numbness on the right side of her knee, but notes that this will improve as the nerves across the knee heal. She has a slight limp, but her gait was controlled using an assist gait sensor. There is mild swelling along the right knee, which the patient reports normalizes with normal gait after 6 weeks of normal activity. She reports that she is happy with how the surgery went. She will write a note to request an additional evaluation in 6 weeks and discuss her job status at that time. She currently works for Ups and is not able to go back to work yet because of going up and down steps with the position she has. However, she is being considered for a telemedicine visit to check in and make sure things are progressing well.


PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.


Musculoskeletal
No pain to palpation of the right knee. Normal reflex time is returned at 6 weeks. Normal gait is normal.
Examination of the left knee shows normal gait with decreased velocity. There is mild swelling along the medial aspect of the knee. No plantarflexion or extension of the lateral aspects of the kneecap. mild swelling to the right.
Neurological
No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema of the bilateral lower extremities.

X-rays of the right knee, 3 weeks after the arthroscopic surgery. Normal reflex time is returned at 6 weeks. The incision is nice and straight. There is no evidence of any fractures or osteoarthritis. The area of numbness on this side will get smaller as the nerves across the skin across the knee heal. The gait was normal. The surgical team did not do anything to the kneecap. The right knee is stable. Annie will bring the x-rays in to the office in 6 weeks and discuss this with the patient. 
ASSESSMENT
• Status post right medial unicompartmental arthroplasty.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well after the surgery. However, she continues to have aches and pains. We will talk again in 6 weeks to assess her further progress.

Patient Agreements: Thepatient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. The patient will contact her primary care physician (PCP) to schedule a follow-up appointment. She will also bring the plan with her today.
INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 6 months to check on her progress.
